The FTSE 100 reached a two week high, helped by positive results from chip designer Arm, while Germany’s Dax jumped sharply as the prospects of further sanctions on Russia seemed to fade. The final scores showed: • The FTSE 100 finished 66.9 points or 0.99% higher at 6795.34 • Germany’s Dax rose 1.27% to 9734.33 • France’s Cac closed 1.5% higher at 4369.52 • Italy’s FTSE MIB added 2.16% to 20,873.5 • Spain’s Ibex ended 1.59% better at 10,648.9 Over in the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 70 points or 0.4% higher. On that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments and we’ll be back tomorrow. Time to recap. The UK government's deficit reduction plans have been questioned after Britain borrowed £11.4bn to balance the books last month, more than expected. Several economists have predicted that the official debt target for this year is "increasingly challenging", just three months into the financial year. John Bulford, economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club warns: The lack of any meaningful improvement relative to June last year is a concern. The positive effects of the Swiss Capital Tax and high earners deferring income from the previous tax year to take advantage of the reduction in the top rate of income tax are beginning to fade. “With central government spending seemingly well under control, most of the disappointment is coming from revenues. The slowdown in growth in VAT receipts is perhaps the biggest let-down, particularly given the apparent strength of the consumer. VAT receipts were up just 4.3% to the same three months a year ago, the worst performance for almost a year.” On an underlying basis, borrowing was little changed compared to a year ago, despite the recovery. The figures provoked a political clash. Treasury insisted that the government's plans were on track (if unfinished), but Labour responded that Britain is off-course. • The latest US inflation data has shown that core prices rose by less than expected in June. Gasoline prices, though, kept the headline cost-of-living rate up at 2.1%. That pushed European stock markets higher this afternoon. • The CBI reported that British factories remain optimistic about future prospects, with investment plans at a record high. Demand has come off the boil a little this month, though, and manufacturers are worried about geopolitical risks. • Royal Bank of Scotland has been accused of being 'wilful obtuse' when testifying to MPs last month. • Royal Mail shares are on track for their lowest closing price since floating last October. They're down 4% this afternoon at 447p, after warning that parcel revenues are below expectations. • And Switzerland's Credit Suisse bank has said it "deeply regrets" its involvement in US tax evasion, after posting its biggest loss since 2008. It could be the best stock market statement ever, suggests the Telegraph's Graham Ruddick. And he's got a point. Property investment firm Panther Securities, run by Tory-turned-UKIP supporter Andrew Perloff, has thrown an almighty strop after seeing its representative kicked off the board of department store Beale. As Panther is the biggest shareholder in Beale, and its 'related parties' have loaned it a million pounds, the move has gone down rather badly. Perloff has used the official stock market news feed to hit back, saying: "I have long held the view that: 1) It is foolish to upset your Landlord. 2) It is foolish to upset those that provide you with finance. 3) It is foolish for a quoted company to upset its largest shareholder. 4) It is foolish to sack a Director who is knowledgeable, well connected and who does not charge a salary or any expenses. In one fell swoop Beales has managed all of these, which must be some type of record! It is hard to understand their logic." Perloff does have 'previous form' for unusual stock market statements - through his "Chairman's ramblings". Enjoy..... The US housing market may be pulling out of its slump -- home resales jumped by 2.6% in June, the fastest rate in eight months. European stock markets have rallied higher on the back of the US inflation report. Traders are calculating that the dip in core inflation means the 'punchbowl' of loose monetary policy isn't running dry, even though the headline rate remained at 2.1%. The FTSE 100 is up 60 points, or 0.9%, with chipmaker ARM still leading the way after decent results and forecasts this morning. The other main bourses are also up at least 1%. The US stock market has also opened slightly higher, with the Dow Jones up 0.2% in early trading. Here's AP's take on the US inflation data: U.S. consumer prices rose in June at a slightly slower pace than in May with two-thirds of the June advance driven by the largest jump in gasoline prices in a year. The Labor Department says prices rose 0.3 percent in June following a 0.4 percent rise in May which had been the biggest one-month gain in more than a year. Energy prices were up 1.6 percent, nearly double the May gain, reflecting a sharp 3.3 percent rise in gasoline costs. But food costs edged up just 0.1 percent, the smallest gain since January. Core prices, which exclude volatile food and energy, were up just 0.1 percent. Over the past 12 months, core prices are up 1.9 percent, an indication of moderate inflation. Economists reckon that the drop in US core inflation, to 1.9% in June, means the Federal Reserve won't fret about inflationary pressure building. And that means less pressure to raise interest rates from their current record low. Here's some instant reaction: The US inflation rate was 2.1% in June, in line with expectations and matching May's figure, according to data just released. On a monthly basis, prices rose by 0.3% compared with May. Higher gasoline prices were a key factor. But core inflation was lower than forecast. Stripping out energy and food prices, 'core inflation' rose by just 0.1% month-on-month, or 1.9% compared with a year ago. At first glance, there's little here to prompt the Federal Reserve into raising interest rates sooner than previously thought. Reaction to follow.... Nearly time for the final event of the day... US inflation. Economists predict that the cost of living rose by 2.1% year-on-year in June. McDonald's continues to struggle to stem its falling sales in the US and Europe. In its latest results, just released, the fast food giant reported that comparable sales across America fell by 1.5% in the April-June quarter. It blamed: ...negative comparable guest traffic amid ongoing broad-based challenges. And in Europe, like-for-like sales fell 1.0% in the quarter, partly due to "ongoing weakness" in Germany. And there's no immediate sign of improvement. McDonald's CEO, Don Thompson, warned that: As such, full year 2014 global comparable sales are expected to be relatively similar to year-to-date June performance, with July global comparable sales expected to be negative. McDonald's also missed profit forecasts, with earnings of $1.40 per share. And its shares have dropped 1.4% in pre-market trading, Royal Bank of Scotland has been accused of being "wilfully obtuse" in front of a committee of MPs, over claims that it deliberately drove small firms to the wall. Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the Treasury Committee, has laid into RBS over evidence given by senior managers to his committee last month. The allegations centre on the bank's "Global Restructuring Group" (GRG). Last month Derek Sach, head of GRG, insisted that the division was not a "profit centre". Now, though, RBS has admitted that Sir Andrew Large, who investigated GRG, was right, and it is a "profit centre" after all (although it still denies deliberately destroying firms to generate profits) Tyrie is seriously unimpressed by RBS's conduct. He says: “RBS had not objected to the term ‘profit centre’ when given extensive opportunity to comment on drafts of Sir Andrew’s report last year. Yet it decided to contest the term in evidence to the Committee, not only in a written statement in February, but also repeatedly in its public hearing in June. Following the Committee’s decision to write to Sir Andrew Large for clarification, RBS has now offered the Committee what it euphemistically describes as ‘additional comments’. In fact, they have done a belated U-turn. It’s not as if the facts have changed. So it now appears that RBS has been wilfully obtuse with the Committee. This isn't the end of the matter. Tyrie is taking the matter up with RBS chairman, Sir Philip Hampton. “If this is how RBS deals with a parliamentary Committee, how much can customers and regulators rely on it to be straightforward with them? “I will be writing to the Chairman of RBS about this, and the Committee will report on it after the summer.” Here's my colleague Jill Treanor's story about last month's hearing: RBS executives deny wrecking small businesses to make a profit Ian Hannam, the City 'rainmaker' who was once one of Britain's most powerful bankers, has, finally, been fined £450,000 for breaching the UK's market abuse rules. The FCA confirmed the penalty this morning, after Hannam lost his final appeal. The case centred on emails which Hannam, then at JP Morgan, had sent to clients in 2008 disclosing information not yet in the public domain. He has repeatedly argued that the messages did not breach market abuse rules, but has now been forced to pay up. Tracey McDermott, the FCA’s director of Enforcement and Financial crime, says City workers should learn from Hannam's example: “This has been a long and complex case but the Tribunal’s substantial judgment is a landmark. It should leave market participants in no doubt that casual and uncontrolled distribution of inside information is not acceptable in today’s markets. Controlling the flow of inside information is a key way of preventing market abuse and we would urge all market participants to pay close attention to the judgment.” Britain's Canary Wharf is heading eastwards, with plans for an extra 3,000 homes and new towers in the Docklands area. It should create thousands more jobs too, as my colleague Julia Kollewe explains: More than 3,000 homes are to be built at the eastern edge of Canary Wharf after Tower Hamlets council gave the green light for the project, the first extension to the financial district since the banking crisis struck in 2008. Canary Wharf Group, which is majority-owned by Songbird, has been granted planning permission to build 30 new buildings, comprising 4.9m sq ft of homes, offices and shops, at Wood Wharf, east of the development. This includes a cylindrical residential skyscraper designed by Herzog & de Meuron, the Swiss architects behind Tate Modern and the "Bird's Nest" Olympic stadium in Beijing. Canary Wharf spreads east with new towers and 3,000 homes planned Britain's factory owners remain optimistic about prospects this summer, although export order growth has tailed off. The CBI's industrial trends survey, released this morning, also found that manufacturers are prepared to invest in new equipment and premises, despite growing worries about geopolitical risks. The CBI said: The balance for new domestic orders (+23%) was the highest since July 1988 (+25%), but export orders (0%) were flat, following growth in the three months to April (+16%) Firms are upbeat about the next quarter, with expectations for total new orders growth at their strongest since 1977, and export orders set to rebound. Looking to the year ahead, there are also encouraging signs: manufacturers’ plans for investment in product and process innovation are at their strongest since 1989, with robust plans for spending on plant & machinery, and buildings. The number of firms investing to expand capacity reached a record high (since 1979). However... the proportion of firms concerned that political and economic conditions abroad may limit export orders rose sharply to a five-quarter high. More details here. The opposition Labour party has seized on today's public finance figures as proof that the government is off course (something the Treasury has tried to 'pre-but' already): Chris Leslie, Labour’s Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury says: “George Osborne is not only set to break his promise to balance the books by next year, he is also borrowing more so far this year than the same period last year. “Borrowing is now expected to be almost £190 billion more than planned under this Government. This is the cost of three damaging years of flat lining and falling living standards we have seen since the election. And with an election due in 10 months, Leslie explains how Labour would (aim to) do better: “As Labour’s National Policy Forum agreed this weekend, Labour will balance the books and get the national debt falling as soon as possible in the next Parliament. But we will get the deficit down more fairly by reforming our economy for the long-term and reversing David Cameron's top rate tax cut for the top one per cent of earners." The Centre for Economics and Business Research reckons whoever wins the next UK general election will have to make "sharp public spending cuts". Here's senior economist Rob Harbron on today's public finance figures: The surprisingly high June result from the public finances leaves the UK’s debt to GDP ratio at 77.3%. This is a new high despite solid GDP growth in 2014, highlighting the size of the debt mountain that will need to be tackled over the next parliament. Harbron also believes the official forecasts are too optimistic: Overall, although the Office for Budget Responsibility forecasts a return to budgetary surplus in 2018/19, Cebr expects a deficit of £22 billion to remain at that point. This is due to the buoyant growth projected by the OBR over the medium term – a time during which Cebr expects economic expansion to be curtailed by sharp but necessary fiscal retraction. Three months into the financial year, Britain's underlying public sector net borrowing is £2.4bn higher than in 2013/2014 (despite falling slightly from £11.5bn to £11.4bn in June). The British Chambers of Commerce's chief economist, David Kern, says that's a worrying sign: The way things are right now, the deficit reduction predicted by the Office of Budget Responsibility appears to be very difficult to achieve. Kern fears that the UK's tax-generating powers may have been permanently hit by the crisis: “Since the financial crisis, weaknesses in the financial sector and structural changes in the rest of the economy have created a major shortfall in the UK’s ability to generate tax revenues, even as economic growth returns to normal. The government must adjust to these new realities and continue to reduce the share of current public spending in GDP. This will be difficult, and perhaps unpopular, but it is essential if we are to secure a lasting recovery.” Samuel Tombs, senior UK Economist at Capital Economics, says today's public finances data show the government is struggling to get the deficit down. Tombs explains: The Office for Budget Responsibility's underlying measure of borrowing – Public sector net borrowing excluding APF and Royal Mail pension fund transfers – was £11.4bn in June, only a fraction lower than June 2013’s £11.5bn. Given April and May’s hefty deficits, this left borrowing in the first three months of the fiscal year 7% higher this year than last. Since the OBR expects the deficit to be about 10% lower this year as a whole, the fiscal consolidation still seems to be off track. But there's good news for George Osborne too -- Tombs reckons the public finances should improve later this year: The annual comparison looks bad partly because tax receipts were boosted in May and June 2013 by the cut in the additional income tax rate. Indeed, corporation tax and VAT receipts have grown more strongly than the OBR expected. What’s more, stronger economic growth than the OBR predicted back in March should help to boost tax receipts and reduce benefits spending faster than set out in the fiscal plans. However.... June’s borrowing numbers underline that the fiscal consolidation still has a long way to go yet before the public finances are restored to a sustainable footing. The Treasury insists that the UK public finances are on course, despite having to borrow £11.4bn in June. Here's the official comment: The government’s long term economic plan is working, delivering economic security for hardworking people. Today’s Public Sector Net Borrowing figures continue to be in line with the budget forecast which predicts the deficit to have halved by the end of this year. But the job is not yet done which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy.” And this chart shows how the UK public finances are, by one measure, rather worse than a year ago. That's because the Bank of England transferred some profits made by buying UK government debt (through its quantitative easing scheme) in June 2013, making the finances look better. This chart underlines how the UK has failed to cut public borrowing so far this year (blue) compared to the 2013-14 financial year (red). Stamp duty revenuue, though, is up more than 43% year on year. Today's public finance figures show the UK government is struggling to bring down the deficit. Here's Reuters' early take: Britain's public finances showed a bigger than expected deficit in June, continuing a weak start to the tax year that leaves finance minister George Osborne with a lot of catching up to do to meet his fiscal goals. The latest figures show the government has so far failed to reduce public borrowing during the first three months of the 2014/15 fiscal year, with less than a year to go before a national election. The public sector finances, excluding financial sector interventions, showed a deficit of £11.368bn in June, the Office for National Statistics said on Tuesday.This is up from £7.594bn in June 2013 and well above analyst forecasts of a deficit of £10.65bn. Stripping out the effect of cash transfers from the Bank of England, the 2014/15 deficit to date was £36.1bn, 7.3% higher than at the same point a year ago. Britain's government is aiming to get the deficit down to 5.5% of gross domestic product in the 2014/15 fiscal year, from 6.5% of GDP in 2013/14.The ONS said that some factors meant that trends in borrowing in the first three months of this tax year might not be representative of the year as a whole. The first three months of 2013 saw higher than usual income tax payments, due to tax changes, and there were also receipts from a Swiss tax avoidance deal. Income tax in the first three months of this tax year was 3.5 percent lower than in the first three months of the 2013/14 tax year. Payments of grants to local authorities also followed a different pattern, an ONS official said. Just in: Britain borrowed £11.386bn to balance the nation's books in June - more than expected, and more than a year ago. Analysts had predicted a deficit of £10.665bn. In June 2013, the UK borrowed £7.594bn (although this was flattered by one-off factors). That's not a great sign for the state of the UK's finances, showing little progress in bringing the deficit down. Details and reaction to follow... European stock markets are all trading higher today, as investors decide they're less worried about geopolitical tensions (for the moment). The news that Ukrainian separatists have handed over the black boxes from flight MH 17 has been taken as a positive sign – despite the intense international outcry over Russia's conduct. FTSE 100: up 40 points at 6768, + 0.6% German DAX: up 44 points at 9654, + 0.44% French CAC: up 12 points at 4317, + 0.3% Mike van Dulken, Head of Research at Accendo Markets, explains: There has been rising speculation of a ceasefire in Gaza being agreed today as US Secretary of State Kerry arrives in the region, while after far too long a wait the black boxes from downed flight MH17 have been handed over to the Ukrainian government/Malaysian experts. UK chipmaker ARM is leading the FTSE 100 risers, up 3.2%, after predicting that revenue growth will accelerate later this year. Saudi Arabia is poised to open its stock market to foreign investment, and analysts believe there could be a rush to join the Arab world’s biggest bourse. Saudi's Capital Market Authority said today it is planning to open the market to direct investment by foreign financial institutions in the first half of 2015. Draft regulations will be released in August. That could lure money from other emerging markets, such as Russia. Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers, says today's warning (and share price drop) shows that Royal Mail's "honeymoon period" is over. The weakness in the parcels performance is a concern, and may prompt questions as to whether this is transient, or whether the change is structural. The fact that this decline has been offset by an improvement in the letters business, which is not a long term area of growth, and cost cutting measures, may help in the shorter term, but these are both temporary reliefs. Royal Mail shares have dropped 2.5% this morning after it warned that revenues from its parcels business isn't meeting expectations. The recently privatised postal operator blamed changes at Amazon for eating into this crucial area of revenue, along with increased competition. Royal Mail warned: Changes to Amazon's minimum order level for free delivery and expansion of its own delivery network have reduced addressable market volumes. Competition in account and consumer/small business parcels has intensified more than expected as other carriers seek to fill capacity in their networks by aggressively reducing prices It's not a full-blown profit warning, though, as letters revenue has held up better than expected. But Moya Greene, Royal Mail CEO, warned that Christmas trading will be crucial. "Our parcels revenue will be dependent on our performance in the second half, which includes the Christmas trading period, and on no further weakening in our addressable UK parcels market." Royal Mail shares slid by 11p to 455p - which, co-incidentally, is the level they closed at when the company was floated on October 11. That's still 37% above the 330p float price. But back in January they were changing hands for over £6. Credit Suisse's results haven't wowed the stock market -- shares are down 0.69% in early trading. Despite that inflow of new money, Credit Suisse's Private Banking and Wealth Management (PBWM) division didn't hit forecasts, due to weaker profit margins. That took the shine off its investment banking arm, which beat forecast by 22%. Espírito Santo Investment Bank analysts warned: "While the investment bank has outperformed this quarter, PBWM continues to disappoint. Credit Suisse's clients haven't deserted it, though, despite the humiliation of pleading guilty to an “extensive and wide-ranging conspiracy” to help US clients evade taxes. Its private banking business attracted 10.1 billion francs of new money in the quarter. Credit Suisse's eye-watering $2.6m penalty for aiding tax evasion has encouraged Swiss banks to change their ways, argues Bernhard Bauhofer of investment bank Sparring Partners. Bauhofer told Bloomberg TV that the case is: "still negatively impacting Credit Suisse, and hurting its reputation worldwide". We're now seeing a completely different picture in Switzerland now, he claimed, with banks changing their models, and growing strongly in Asia. Shareholders in Credit Suisse are counting the cost of the bank's involvement with US tax evasion this morning, after it reported its biggest loss since the financial crisis erupted in 2008. Credit Suisse posted a loss of 700 million Swiss francs, or £457m, for the last quarter this morning, a sharp reversal on the 1.05bn Swiss francs earned a year ago. That's a bigger loss than expected. It was dragged deep into the red by the $2.6bn charge agreed with American authorities for helping US citizens to avoid tax in May. Chief executive Brady Dougan insists that Credit Suisse deeply regretted its past activities, having been forced to plead guilty to the crime of aiding US tax evasion. Dougan said: "I want to reiterate that we deeply regret the past misconduct that led to this settlement and that we take full responsibility for it. "The continued trust and support of our clients helped us mitigate the impact of the settlement on our business." The Credit Suisse fine, and guilty plea, looks like a landmark moment in the battle between tax authorities and banks who profited from offering their clients' secrecy. And in another a sign of the changes in banking, Credit Suisse says it will now wind down its commodities trading arm, to focus on more profitable areas. Reaction to follow.... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business. It's a busy day for economic news, both in Britain and the US. In the UK, the latest public finance figures are released at 9.30am - showing how much the government had to borrow to balance the books in June. Economists expect a slight improvement, with public sector net borrowing dropping to just(?) £9.4bn, from £11.5bn in May. At 11am, the CBI's latest industrial trends survey will show how UK factories fared last month. Then at 1.30pm, the biggie -- the US inflation rate for June. Traders will be eying this release for signs of inflationary pressure building in the American economy; a factor in when the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates. Stan Shamu of IG explains: The market is looking for a 0.2% month-on-month rise which implies an annual run rate of 2%. We also have existing home sales and the Richmond manufacturing index on the calendar. We'll also be keeping an eye on Greece, where ministers were yesterday urged to hurry up and implement various measures before its troika of lenders return to Athens: In the corporate world, results from Royal Mail and Credit Suisse will get attention this morning -- with Apple, Microsoft and McDonalds reporting tonight. And European stock markets are expected to rise modestly, after a decent day's trading in Asia: I'll be tracking the main events through the day as usual....

webTitle: FTSE 100 hits two week high as Ukraine tensions ease and Arm jumps 6%

fields.standfirst: Investors take heart from latest on Malaysian air crash and Gaza ceasefire hopes
fields.body:
Leading shares finished at their best level for two weeks as geopolitical tensions eased and in the corporate world chip designer Arm beat market expectations.

The FTSE 100 added 66.90 points or 0.99% to 6795.34, with other global markets also moving higher.

News that pro-Russian rebels in Ukraine had complied with Western requests to hand over the black box recorders from the crashed Malaysian Airlines plane gave investors some comfort. The threat of further sanctions against Russia seemed to ease during the day, while there was a new push to broker a ceasefire in Gaza. With these more hopeful signs emerging, traders were free to concentrate on the underlying strength of the global economy.

One beneficiary was Arm, which added 47.5p to 881p after it reported a 9% rise in second quarter profits to £94.2m, boosted by a 42% rise in licensing revenues. There was also vague talk it could be a bid target for one of the major US technology companies.

Mining shares were also among the gainers as investors rediscovered their appetite for risk assets. Anglo American added 55p to 1600.5p after one of its main profit generators, Kumba Iron Ore in South Africa, reported better than expected results. A fall in iron ore export prices led to a 16% fall in earnings, with overseas sales volumes dipping slightly. But domestic sales volumes rose by 40%, helped by a new supply deal with ArcelorMittal in South Africa.

Fresnillo was up 22p at 937.5p and Antofagasta moved 15.5p higher to 831p. Petropavlovsk put on 1.5p to 36.75p after the Russian gold mining group confirmed its full year production guidance despite a 7% fall in second quarter output.

But Royal Mail disappointed, closing at its lowest ever level since October's flotation. It fell 16p to 450p after its first quarter update showed a 2% rise in revenues. There was a better then expected performance from letters, with volumes down 3% rather than the forecast 4% to 5%, but its parcels business was hit by increased competition.

Supermarkets came under pressure as analysts continued to weigh up the possible repercussions of Philip Clarke's departure from Tesco. With worries about a possible price war, Tesco dropped 11.3p to 277.35p, J Sainsbury slid 4.5p to 313.8p and Morrisons lost 2.2p to 171.5p.

Among the mid-caps IG jumped 44.5p to 619.5p after the spread betting group said full year revenues rose 2.4% to £370.4m, with a 21% increase in the full year dividend. But Croda closed down 43p at £21.71 as the chemicals maker repeated last month's warning that full year profits would be lower than last year's, partly due to the strong pound. But the company, whose chemicals are used in cosmetics, pesticides and detergents, said underlying profits should make progress. Half year profits fell 5.9% to £125.3m, not helped by weak consumer demand in Europe. In a hold note, Numis said there were "no fresh negatives but [the] dull top line still an issue."

Liberum was more negative, issuing a sell note with a £20 price target.

As previously mentioned three factors have hurt the published results a) foreign exchange translation headwinds; b) a weak performance in Industrial Chemicals (commodity fatty acids) where second quarter profits declined almost 60% in cc terms from a year ago; and c) weaker mix in Consumer Care Division as healthcare is growing faster than personal care or cropcare and is slightly lower margin. No changes to 2014 consensus are likely having been cut at the June warning stage, which is £240m pretax profit and 126.7p earnings per share. We have a sell rating on the shares arguing that structural factors have weighed on top line development in Consumer Care over the last 6 quarters not just ephemeral factors such as the weather, weak Europe and foreign exchange. These structural challenges are not going away quickly and suggest that the group's 2014 PE of nearly 18 times remains unwarranted.

Elsewhere Nick Leslau's Max Property built up a 12.75p gain to 168p as it announced a sale of its portfolio for £447m two years ahead of schedule, a return of 184p a share in cash to shareholders and the winding up of the company. The sale to Blackstone followed an approach from the investment group which Max said represented an attractive return for investors. Analysts at Peel Hunt said:

The return to shareholders of 184p is 8% below our Mar 2016 basic net asset value forecast, but this difference is largely accounted for by the increase to the management fees that are now payable (14.5p).
Max has taken advantage of the strong investor market to sell the entire portfolio in one transaction and, following the sale, Max will have made a compounded, annual return of 13% pa since floating in 2009.

Finally Toumaz rose 6% to 6.25p after Spire Healthcare's Montefiore Hospital in Brighton became the first to start using a new wireless vital signs monitoring device made by the company's Sensium Healthcare subsidiary.

The monitor is a lightweight, wireless patch attached to the patient's chest with sensors taking readings of heart rate, respiration and temperature. The data is then sent wirelessly to nurse stations and handheld devices. If readings exceed pre-set levels, alerts are sent to nurses who are then able to intervene immediately.

webTitle: Government borrowing is rising, but there is no sign of panic in the City

fields.standfirst: June figures have sent long-term trend into reverse, but City's low-key response suggests analysts think it may be a blip
fields.body:
At first glance the government's finances look a little sick. Official figures show borrowing is rising when the direction of travel is supposed to be down.

Compared with the UK's neighbours, the annual deficit remains large and the trajectory long. France and Italy, both supposedly in a bigger economic hole, are closer to the European commission target of 3%.

At this point in the recovery, there was a reasonable expectation that soaring tax receipts and a check on government spending would dramatically reduce the budget deficit. And bit by bit, that has been the story of the last couple of years. June sent the trend into reverse.

But there is no sign of panic in the City. It is a long time since anyone worried about the reaction of bond traders to each decimal point increase in a government budget deficit. The eurozone is guaranteed by the European Central Bank. The Bank of England has shown itself willing to print money to cover the UK's deficit if need be.

And anyway, analysts reckon the June figure is a blip before reverting to the previous trend. There is a good deal of blame for one-off factors and the distorting effects of taking the Royal Mail's pension scheme on to the public ledger. Higher benefit spending was another culprit.

The Treasury, recognising the potential for negative headlines, issued a press release within minutes of the figures coming out. It made clear that George Osborne expects a bumper tax receipt windfall in the new year to put his deficit reduction forecast back on track.

Tax receipts are already on the increase after VAT receipts rose 5.5% year-on-year, stamp duty jumped 43%, income tax increased by 2.3% and corporation tax by a healthy 17.9%.

Yet a bigger rise from self-assessment receipts in January 2015 is far from certain. Wages remain depressed and it is not clear how many skilled, well-paid jobs have been created. More importantly, the biggest boost to employment comes from the 700,000 self-employed people who have pushed employment totals to new highs. The Treasury can only guess at their impact. It doesn't know how many are in low-paid, part-time work. It doesn't know if they will earn enough to pay tax at all.

webTitle: Canary Wharf spreads east with new towers and 3,000 homes planned

fields.bodyText: More than 3,000 homes are to be built at the eastern edge of Canary Wharf after Tower Hamlets council approved the project, the first extension to the financial district since the 2008 banking crisis. Canary Wharf Group, majority-owned by Songbird Estates, has been granted planning permission to construct 30 buildings, comprising 4.9m square feet of homes, offices and shops, at Wood Wharf, just a stone's throw from the headquarters of some of the world's largest banks. Homes at Wood Wharf will range from parkside townhouses to towers, with a mix of private and social housing. Its centrepiece is also the tallest building, a 211-metre 57-storey cylindrical residential skyscraper facing the waters of South Dock, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, the Swiss architects behind Tate Modern (including its extension which is being built at the moment) and the "Bird's Nest" Olympic stadium in Beijing. About a quarter of the "habitable rooms" of the 3,100 homes will be earmarked for affordable housing, built around 3.6 hectares (9 acres) of parks and public squares, including hundreds of metres of dockside paths. A Tower Hamlets council spokesman said the project "will make a strategic contribution to both the council's housing and employment needs". He added: "The development will be well-supported by a proposed new primary school, health facility and an idea store [library], along with 25% on-site affordable housing... This development will contribute to the continued growth of the north Docklands area as one of the most exciting and vibrant places to live and work in London." Lutfur Rahman, the mayor of Tower Hamlets, said: "It will generate thousands of jobs for local residents, it will create high quality affordable homes, and the development itself will be an iconic addition to Tower Hamlets." Developers have been rushing to build more luxury homes in London to exploit booming property prices, with Canary Wharf Group just starting construction of its first residential building on the western edge of the finance district, the 58-storey Newfoundland tower (nicknamed the Diamond tower) with 566 apartments, which is due to be completed in 2018. More than 100,000 workers commute daily to Canary Wharf, which opened in the early 1990s. Sir George Iacobescu, chief executive of Canary Wharf Group, believes the eastern extension will almost double the number of people working and living in the area within the next ten years. Work on the Wood Wharf site is expected to start this autumn with the first buildings occupied at the end of 2018, to coincide with the arrival of Crossrail, the £15bn railway running east-west across London. The new area will include offices targeted at technology start-ups and creative media, as well as a 420-place primary school, an NHS medical centre, a hotel and more than 100 shops, restaurants and cafes. The project, the biggest in the developer's pipeline, is expected to create more than 17,000 jobs during its construction, ranging from architects and planners to electricians, with 3,500 earmarked for local residents. Canary Wharf Group paid £90m to take full control of the Wood Wharf site two years ago from its joint venture partners Waterways and Ballymore. Canary Wharf is home to the global headquarters of Barclays and HSBC, and the London headquarters of investment banks JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and Citigroup. However, the Financial Conduct Authority is moving further east, to Stratford, by 2018. In its first foray outside the Docklands, Canary Wharf Group – whose parent Songbird is part-owned by Qatar Holding, the investment arm of the Gulf state – is also revamping London's South Bank, around the Shell Centre tower, in partnership with Qatari Diar, the Gulf state's property investment company.

webTitle: A banking change is just around the corner

fields.standfirst: If another banking inquiry can't sort out the banks then digital finance soon will - look what happened to travel agents
fields.body:
Another banking inquiry has been announced, meaning more senior executives will be dragged over the coals, more promises of change, and more disappointment when the problems can't be solved. The mood on the street towards banks seems to have moved from outrage to a tired, distrusting apathy.

There is a good side to all this. The banks themselves might not be changing, but banking most definitely is. Financial services are being turned upside down by digital technology.

This year alternative finance providers will channel around £850m of funding into UK small businesses – just over 1% of all business lending – a mere drop in the ocean. But don't let that fool you. The alternative market has nearly tripled in size over the last six months. By growing 150% year-on-year, alternative finance providers could account for nearly half of the business lending market by 2018. That, frankly, feels conservative against the backdrop of other internet powered markets.

Industries from music, to publishing, to travel have all been made unrecognisable by the impact of the internet. The thought of using a travel agent to book your holiday might feel like a bygone age to many readers, but just 10 years ago it was the norm. Similarly in five years time we'll think it unimaginable to have to wait weeks on end for a bank branch manager to approve a business loan.

The internet has accelerated everything. In the past, market dominant companies grew steadily over time. Marks & Spencer was founded in 1884, and it was 17 years before they opened a second market stall. Contrast that with Amazon, which was founded in 1994. Last year, after just 19 years in business, Amazon's revenues were nearly $75bn. And again contrast that with Facebook, which barely existed 10 years ago, or YouTube which was only founded in 2005.

The reason that the internet fosters such growth is that it can deliver better, more transparent products for consumers. Ten years ago, if you wanted to book a holiday you went to a travel agent, where you sat and watched while they punched your details into a computer and you were then told a flat price. You had no way of negotiating a cheaper flight or better hotel other than to walk next door and repeat the process all over again. The internet has made every facet of booking a holiday more transparent, and therefore enabled consumers to get a better deal. The same can be achieved for banking.

Last week I explained this view to the Treasury select committee. Before I sat in front of the panel of MPs, they spent over an hour grilling representatives of two of the UK's biggest banks for a series of fundamental failures in helping businesses access and understand finance. Their exchange only highlighted the contrast between the old and new of business finance. These bank failures reflect an old world, characterised by opaque products, complex fees and charges, and a general lack of regard for the customer. Technology-driven financial services providers can't treat you this way. If one travel website charges you more for the same hotel than a second travel website, there is no hiding place. The same is true for the new finance providers. The new world of banking should be characterised by transparency, speed and accessibility.

Thousands of successful, intelligent businesses are already using alternative finance to grow and explore new opportunities. These businesses are the pioneers of what will soon become a standard practice, like the early customers of eBay or Amazon, and the first viewers of YouTube.

Banking in the UK is about to change dramatically. But it won't happen in dusty old rooms discussing dusty old problems; like so many other industries, the change will be driven by technology.

• Anil Stocker is Co-Founder and CEO of MarketInvoice – a leading peer-to-peer finance provider

webTitle: Anglo American gains after iron ore division beats estimates

fields.standfirst: Mining sector helps support markets as investors move back into risk assets
fields.body:
Mining shares are among the gainers as investors rediscover their appetite for risk assets.

In particular Anglo American has added 40p to 1585.5p after one of its main profit generators, Kumba Iron Ore in South Africa, reported better than expected results. A fall in iron ore export prices led to a 16% fall in earnings, with overseas sales volumes dipping slightly. But domestic sales volumes rose by 40%, helped by a new supply deal with ArcelorMittal in South Africa. Analysts at RBC Capital Markets said:

Kumba reported headline earnings of $606m; after accounting for consolidation adjustments, Kumba contributed $409m to Anglo's net earnings, coming in above our $339m forecast. Kumba comprises around 35% of our forecast first half earnings; we expect this result to have a positive impact on our earnings forecasts for Anglo.
Anglo reports first half 2014 results on Friday morning. Consensus forecast operating profit is $3.0bn with RBC at $2.8bn and earnings per share at $0.93 a share (RBC $0.89 a share).

Still in the mining sector, Fresnillo is up 20.5p at 936p and Antofagasta is 18p higher at 833.5p.

webTitle: Government borrowing figures dent deficit reduction target

fields.bodyText: The coalition government borrowed more than expected in June, putting chancellor George Osborne further off course in his plan to reduce the deficit. Borrowing totalled £11.4bn over the month, higher than the £10.7bn forecast by economists, and £3.8bn more than in June 2013. Stripping out the impact of a one-off cash transfer from the Bank of England in June last year, borrowing in the first three months of the 2014-15 fiscal year was £36.1bn, 7.3% higher than the same period last year, according to the Office for National Statistics. At the time of the March budget, the Office for Budget Responsibility – the Treasury's independent forecaster – predicted a fall in government borrowing this year to £95.5bn, from £105.8bn in 2013-14. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The overall performance for April-June has clearly not been the start to fiscal year 2014-15 that George Osborne would have been looking for. One-quarter of the way into the tax year it looks like the chancellor faces a battle to achieve his fiscal targets for 2014-15 and he will certainly need growth to hold up." Economists said that the state of the public purse should improve later in the fiscal year. The annual comparison looks bad partly because of higher-than-usual income tax payments early last year, which were the result of tax changes. The figures last year were also boosted by receipts from a Swiss tax avoidance deal. The Treasury said: "Today's public sector net borrowing figures continue to be in line with the budget forecast, which predicts the deficit to have halved by the end of this year. But the job is not yet done which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy." The UK's national debt was £1.3tn at the end of June, equivalent to 77.3% of GDP. Chris Leslie MP, Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "Borrowing is now expected to be almost £190bn more than planned under this government. This is the cost of three damaging years of flatlining and falling living standards we have seen since the election."

webTitle: UBM should sell cut dividend and sell newswire business, says broker

fields.standfirst: Panmure Gordon advises new chief executive to focus company on its events business
fields.body:
Trade show and newswire business UBM has fallen back in a rising market after a broker report calling on the company's chief executive to take drastic action.

Panmure Gordon analyst Jonathan Helliwell cut his recommendation from buy to sell, on the basis that any revamp of the business could hurt it in the short term, as the same time as it suffers adverse currency pressures.

Helliwell said new chief executive Tim Cobbold, who started in May, should cut the company's dividend and sell PRNewswire to leave the company as a high growth, pure global events business. He said:

However, this could hurt the stock in the near term. We also argue that consensus estimates look around 11% too high reflecting foreign exchange pressures and near term constraints in events. We move our price target from 940p to 590p and our rating from buy to sell.

He added:

We believe that over time UBM could reinvest proceeds from a sale of PRNewswire (£480m estimated) at a return on investment equal to or better than the return achieved on a PRN sale (6.2% post tax estimated).
Meantime a dividend cut would repair cover and generate a free cash flow of up to £100m per annum to invest in the global events sector, where M&A opportunities remain significant. However, either course of action could be negative for the stock at least in the near term. A dividend cut would take away any yield support. A sale of PRN could be significantly earnings per share-dilutive in the near term (up to 33% on our estimates, depending on tax) and introduces significant execution risk both on the sale and reinvestment.

UBM's shares are currently 6.5p lower at 648p.

webTitle: Arm adds 3% after 9% profit rise as markets recover from Ukraine concerns

fields.standfirst: Chip designer boosted by strong licensing demand but royalty revenues disappoint
fields.body:
As markets shrug off the current geopolitical tensions - the shooting down of the Malaysian passenger jet, calls for tougher sanctions on Russia, violence in Gaza - chip designer Arm is leading the way.

The company's shares have climbed 23.5p to 857p after it reported a 9% rise in second quarter profits to £94.2m, boosted by strong demand to licence its technology. Licensing revenues rose 42% but royalties grew by just 2%. The company - whose technology is used by the likes of Apple and Samsung - said:

Market data indicates improving semiconductor industry conditions, leading to the expectation of an acceleration in royalty revenue growth in the second half of 2014.

Investors had been nervous about the outlook, with Samsung recently warning of slower global growth for smartphones. But the sector should receive a boost when Apple unveils its iPhone 6, expected around September. Analyst Julian Yates at Investec said:

Headline pretax profit was in line and the outlook intact, but the mix shift between royalties and licences continues. Royalties were up just 2% due to inventory destocking (especially 3G phones in Asia), but licences grew 42%. We expect to lower our second half royalty forecast, but expect this to be offset by upgrades to second half licences. Royalty weakness is not ideal, but it should bounce back as the 4G cycle kicks in, with licence strength underpinning the mid-term outlook. We see current weakness as a buying opportunity.

But Liberum, a consistent seller of the stock, saw no need to change its tune:

Arm's second quarter results are in line with expectations, but this is a combination of strength in licensing and weakness once again in royalties. Ahead of a meeting of European foreign ministers, with Russian sanctions on the agenda, investor sentiment has been lifted by news that Ukrainian separatists had handed over the black boxes from the crashed plane as requested.

The focus also turned back to corporate news, with the reporting season in full swing. Royal Mail disappointed, down 6.8p at 459.2p after its first quarter update showed a 2% rise in revenues. Having reviewed a number of areas that could provide potential encouragement, we see no urgency to revisit the sector - most particularly given the overhanging structural issues. As Tesco's warning [on profits] highlighted, the UK market remains very competitive and we think that the autumn reporting period is unlikely to bring investors any real reassurance.

Among the mid-caps IG has jumped nearly 7% to 613.5p after the spread betting group said full year revenues rose 2.4% to £370.4m, with a 21% increase in the full year dividend. Numis said:

IG reported earnings per share a little ahead of our 40.0p forecasts at 40.2p. For us however, the 28% increase in the final dividend to 22.4p with an increase in the ongoing payout ratio to 70% was by far the most significant piece of new information. IG now has a 4.9% historic yield with a dividend policy that remains progressive.
With the group's capital position remaining strong and forecast to continue to increase 'The board will continue to monitor the capital structure of the business closely'. We believe IG offers good value on a historic multiple of 14 times earnings.

Elsewhere Petropavlovsk put on 9% to 38.5p after the Russian gold mining group confirmed its full year production guidance despite a 7% fall in second quarter output.
